thread.title: SA’s trade deficit widens sharply in August | Economy
thread.title_full: SA’s trade deficit widens sharply in August | Economy | BDlive

author: Ntsakisi Maswanganyi
title: SA’s trade deficit widens sharply in August | Economy
text:
Picture: THINKSTOCK Related articles ECONOMIC WEEK AHEAD: Vicious circle of job losses and low growth Rand firmer ahead of local trade data SOUTH Africa’s trade deficit widened sharply to R9.9bn in August from R1.1bn in July, South African Revenue Service data showed on Wednesday.
July’s data was revised downwards from a R400m surplus.
The deficit in August was much worse than expected, and implies the current account deficit could widen again in the third quarter — which could in turn cause further rand weakness.
Exports decreased by R5.5bn, or 5.9%, to R87.6bn while imports increased by R3.4bn, or 3.6% to R97.6bn.
But the trade balance looks in a much better position compared with this time last year. The cumulative deficit for 2015 is R36.3bn compared to R69.94 billion in 2014.
China, Germany, the US, Botswana and Namibia were the top five countries that SA exported to in August. China, Germany, the US, India and Nigeria were the top five countries which SA imported from.
